Sure! Here is the VPython code that illustrates the physics experiment of horizontal projectile motion with the specified settings and input variable mapping:

```python
from vpython import *

# Screen Settings
scene.width = 700
scene.height = 400

# Cyber Input Variable Mapping
Height_I = 5

# Constants
g = 9.81  # acceleration due to gravity

# Objects
ground = box(pos=vector(0, 0, 0), size=vector(10, 0.1, 5), color=color.green)
ball = sphere(pos=vector(0, Height_I, 0), radius=0.5, color=color.red)
ball.velocity = vector(5, 0, 0)  # initial horizontal velocity

# Animation Loop
while True:
    rate(60)
    
    ball.pos.x += ball.velocity.x * 0.1  # horizontal motion
    
    # vertical motion under gravity
    ball.velocity.y -= g * 0.1
    ball.pos.y += ball.velocity.y * 0.1
    
    if ball.pos.y <= ball.radius:  # collision with ground
        ball.pos.y = ball.radius
        ball.velocity.y *= -1  # elastic bounce
``` 

This code sets up the VPython scene with the specified screen settings and implements the physics experiment of horizontal projectile motion. The initial height of the ball is mapped to the variable `Height_I`, and the animation will rerun whenever the value of `Height_I` changes.
